meta.title: Metabolism in Fed, Fasting, Starvation & Diabetic States

questions.text: The choice of metabolic fuel to meet body energy demand varies depending on availability. Which of the following is the preferred fuel for the body in a fasting state?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fats The preferred fuel for the body in the Fasting state is mainly Fats. Fats stored in adipose tissues are broken down into fatty acids which undergo oxidation to give energy during fasting and starvation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: A. Carbohydrates are the main source of fuel in the fed state. Dietary carbohydrates provide energy for 2 hours after diet. After that glycogen provides energy and can last up to 12-18 hours. RBC only uses glucose under all conditions as it lacks the mitochondria required for the beta-oxidation of fatty acid. Option: C. Under starvation conditions, the body starts using Proteins for energy when all carbohydrates and some fats are used up. However, body try to minimize the protein use by adapting to use ketone bodies produced from the fatty acid as fuel. Option: D. Under fasting/starvation, amino acids are released from muscle protein degradation and travel to the liver for use as energy and provide substrate for gluconeogenesis. Alanine is the most glucogenic amino acid and is released from fasting muscle and undergoes the Cahill cycle. Excess dietary amino acids from protein-rich diets can also contribute to a significant amount of energy under fed state.

questions.text: Food products made of carbohydrates with low glycemic index help control blood sugar levels and are recommended for diabetics. Which of the following has the highest glycemic index?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Galactose Glycemic index (GI): It is a measure of the Increase in blood glucose after the test dose of carbohydrate compared with that of an equivalent amount of glucose. Glucose and galactose have a glycemic index of 1 (or 100%), the same as maltose, isomaltose, lactose, and trehalose, which form these monosaccharides on hydrolysis. GI is a value assigned to foods based on how slowly or how quickly those foods cause an increase in blood glucose levels. Foods with low-GI values are the preferred choice as they are slowly digested and absorbed, causing a slower and smaller rise in blood sugar levels. On the other hand, foods with a high GI value should be limited since they are quickly digested and absorbed, resulting in a rapid rise and fall in blood sugar levels Low GI (≤55) Fructose, beans, grains Medium GI (56-69) Table sugar or sucrose High GI (≥70) High fructose corn syrup, glucose, sweets, rice, maltose 1996

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: A. Fructose and sugar alcohols (sorbitol) have a lower glycemic index. As they are absorbed slowly and incompletely Option: B. The average glycemic index of sucrose is about 65 and varies between 56-69 depending upon variable rates of hydrolysis. Sucrose also has low glycemic index than glucose as it gets split into glucose and fructose

questions.text: A key metabolite formed and utilized under fed and fasting states is acetyl-CoA. The major source of acetyl-CoA under a fed state is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pyruvate Acetyl-CoA is formed in the metabolism of carbohydrates, fats & proteins. However, in the fed-state, the major source of fuel utilized is carbohydrates followed by fats and proteins. So, in the fed state major source of acetyl-CoA will be c a rbohydrates . Carbohydrate gets broken down to Glucose which forms pyruvate & then acetyl CoA by glycolysis and link reaction respectively. So the best answer here is Pyruvate.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: A and B. Triglycerides and fatty acids (formed from the breakdown of adipose TG) are the main fuel sources in fasting and starvation conditions. Upon action by HSL, TG will give rise to fatty acids which will travels to liver via blood and form acetyl-CoA by beta-oxidation. Option: D. Alanine is an amino acid released from protein degradation in a fasting muscle cell. It travels to the liver and forms pyruvate by transamination. Pyruvate is then converted to glucose by gluconeogenesis without the formation of acetyl- This is known as the Cahill cycle. Pyruvate formed from alanine can also form acetyl-CoA for use in TCA. The catabolic intermediates of amino acids threonine, leucine, Isoleucine, and tryptophan can directly give rise to acetyl-CoA.

questions.text: A 28 years old man suffering from intractable vomiting is presented to a hospital and was unable to eat or drink for the past 3 days. His blood analysis still shows a normal glucose level. Which of the following process is mainly responsible for the blood glucose maintenance in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Liver gluconeogenesis As the patient has not taken any food for the past 3 days, he is in a starvation state. Glucagon released under starvation will cause the activation of gluconeogenic enzymes in the liver which will maintain the blood glucose needed for the functioning of vital organs such as the brain and heart and RBCs. So, the answer is liver gluconeogenesis. The figure below shows the role of the liver in the fed and fasting state under hormonal control. Fed state is mainly related to glycogen metabolism while fasted state shows a process related to gluconeogenesis from gluconeogenic substrates

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: B. Dietary glucose can provide blood glucose up to 2 hours after feeding. The extra glucose consumed in food gets deposited in the liver and muscles as glycogen and fats in adipose tissues. Option: C. The glycogenolysis of muscle gives glucose 6-phosphate as an end-product and not glucose due to the absence of the enzyme glucose 6-phosphatase in muscles. Hence, muscle glycogen cannot contribute to blood glucose directly. Option: D. Glycogen breakdown in the liver can maintain blood glucose for 12-18 hours. After that period, liver gluconeogenesis is the main source of blood glucose during fasting/starvation.

questions.text: When the body is devoid of any external source of food for 18 hours or longer, the main source of fuel utilized will be from:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adipose tissue 18 hours or longer is considered a stage of fasting . There will be the release of glucagon which will activate hormone-sensitive lipase in the adipose tissue . This enzyme will act on adipose TG reserves to release fatty acids that will travel to the liver via blood and form acetyl CoA by beta-oxidation. questions.text: Which one of the following tissues can metabolize glucose, fatty acids, and ketone bodies for ATP production?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Muscle Muscles can use all three glucose, fatty acids & ketone bodies . It mainly uses glucose in the fed state, fatty acids in the fasting state and fatty acid and ketone bodies in starvation.

RBCs cannot use fatty acids & ketone bodies, as the metabolism of these takes place in mitochondria which is absent in RBCs.

questions.text: Ketone bodies are formed and utilized by various organs (brain, heart, etc) as the major sources of energy during fasting/starvation. The increase in the formation of ketone bodies during fasting is a result of:

options.label: B
options.text: Decrease in the formation of Acetyl CoA in the liver

options.label: C
options.text: Increased levels of free fatty acids in the blood

options.label: D
options.text: Inhibition of β-oxidation of fatty acids in the liver

questions.correct_answer: C. Increased levels of free fatty acids in the blood
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased levels of free fatty acids in the blood In fasting, free fatty acids bound to albumin are increased due to increased activity of Hormone-sensitive lipase in adipose tissue as this enzyme breaks TG into glycerol & fatty acids . These fatty acids are taken up by the liver. β-oxidation of these fatty acids in the liver provides the acetyl CoA for ketogenesis. Hepatic ketogenesis is also stimulated by elevated levels of glucagon during fasting.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: A. The release of glucagon, a catabolic hormone, is increased during fasting to stimulate various catabolic pathways required for the breakdown of stored carbohydrates and fats. Option: B and D. Excess FFA coming to the liver from adipose TG breakdown results in an increase in acetyl-CoA formation in the liver through increased beta-oxidation in the liver (see figure above) Learning objective: In fasting/starvation, ketone bodies are formed as a result of increased FFA coming into the liver by the increased breakdown of adipose tissue TG by the action of HSL.

questions.text: Following are the test done for proteins, sugar & ketones. Which will be positive in the starvation state in urine?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Only 3 The 3 rd tube shows a positive Rothera’s test for the detection of ketone Tests for detection of ketone bodies Rothera’s test The purple color ring at the junction of 2 liquids = Positive test Given positive by Acetoacetate & Acetone Gerhard’s test Given positive by Acetoacetate only Test for β-Hydroxy Butyrate – as this is the main ketone body found in the blood and urine of patients during ketoacidosis No specific test available for β-Hydroxy Butyrate So, in the sample, β-Hydroxy Butyrate is first oxidized to acetoacetate Then we can perform Rothera’s or Gerhard’s test. In Starvation, Excess of TG breakdown and acetyl CoA formation leads to an increase in ketone body formation which eventually starts coming in urine. So, urine will give a positive test for ketone bodies.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Options: B and D. This is positive Benedict’s test shown. It is done for reducing sugar. It’s a semi-quantitative test and color depends on the amount of carbohydrates present in the sample In starvation, there is no intake of any carbohydrates, and glucose is maintained at minimal levels by liver gluconeogenesis for use by vital organs, so there is no excretion of glucose or any other reducing sugar in the urine. Option: A. The first tube is showing a positive biuret test for protein. It is positive only if the sample molecule has at least 2 peptide bonds In starvation, the body starts utilizing muscle proteins by degrading them to their respective amino acids. So, there will be amino acid breakdown products in the urine such as ammonia and urea but the protein will not be present.

questions.text: Patient with Type I diabetes mellitus, with complaints of polyuria. Which of the following is commonly occurring in this state in his body?

options.label: C
options.text: Increased conversion of fatty acid to acetyl-CoA

questions.correct_answer: C. Increased conversion of fatty acid to acetyl-CoA
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased conversion of fatty acid to acetyl-CoA Metabolic change in DM: K etoacidosis – due to an increase in plasma-free fatty acid. The low insulin condition will promote the activity of HSL to release FFA which undergoes β-oxidation in the liver to form acetyl-CoA Hyperglycemia -It is primarily due to reduced glucose uptake by tissues and its increased production via gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: A. Glycogenesis in muscle As the conditions are catabolic in the absence of insulin, glycogenesis will also be inhibited Options: B. Increased protein synthesis Insulin increases protein synthesis. But in DM 1 insulin deficiency is present so protein synthesis is decreased, and protein degradation is increased Option: D. Decreased cholesterol synthesis As acetyl CoA is the starting material for cholesterol, so, there is increased cholesterol synthesis in DM due to the high acetyl-CoA present in the liver as a result of lipolysis. The activity of the enzyme lipoprotein lipase is low in diabetic patients. Consequently, the plasma levels of VLDL, chylomicrons, and triacylglycerols are increased.

questions.text: The respiratory quotient (RQ) is a useful quantity to measure the energy expenditure of an organism to know certain metabolic states of the body. In Diabetes, What happens to RQ:

options.label: B
options.text: RQ increases & on giving Insulin it again decreases

options.label: C
options.text: RQ is not affected in Diabetes

options.label: D
options.text: RQ decreases & on giving Insulin it again increases

questions.correct_answer: D. RQ decreases & on giving Insulin it again increases
questions.explanation:
Solution:

RQ decreases & on giving Insulin it again increases In a normal person in a fed state, the main fuel for the body is carbohydrates . But in a diabetic patient, the main fuel for the body is fats as carbohydrate/glucose is not entering the cells due to relative or absolute deficiency of insulin. So, RQ decreases in Diabetes as the RQ of fats is less than the RQ for carbohydrates. But on giving Insulin, RQ again rises as glucose starts entering cells through GLUT-4 and now cells will again start using glucose.
